Award.AwardTitle: Intersite Coupling and Entropy in Correlated Electron Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract: Correlated electron materials have technical importance as functional materials with controllable electrical and magnetic properties. This project will provide a unified understanding, which does not now exist, of the inter-relation of structure and chemistry of such materials with their functional properties, to establish an effective route for the design of improved new functional materials. Undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in crystal growth and characterization of correlated electron materials, and in cross-disciplinary interactions with solid state chemists and in international collaborations.

Technical Abstract: The low temperature physics of correlated electron materials is the physics of entropy release from strongly coupled electronic itinerant and local moment degrees of freedom. This project will show how the temperature scale for this release is determined by the structure and chemistry of the materials, establishing a new unified understanding extending from the f- into the transition metal intermetallic compounds, with consequent importance for the design of new functional materials. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained during this study in the crystal growth and characterization of new intermetallic materials and in cross-disciplinary interactions with solid state chemists and in international collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the rare earth containing correlated electron materials studied, mobile conduction electrons interact with localized atomic magnetic moments in the solid. This interaction mediates a coupling between the local magnetic moments, which can lead to magnetic order in the solid at a temperature corresponding to the strength of this coupling. In competition with this ordering, this same interaction between conduction electrons and atomic moments tries to align the magnetic moment carried by the conduction electron opposite to that of the local atomic moments, cancelling out the local atomic moment. It is an empirical observation that when the strength of these competing tendencies are comparable, superconductivity often occurs and a goal in the study of correlated electron materials is to learn how to raise the superconducting transition temperature of materials in this situation, where the highest observed superconducting transition temperatures are believed to occur.

     In conventional superconductors, the interaction between electrons that leads to their condensation into a superconducting state is the electron coupling to lattice vibrations. The relevant energy scale of the lattice vibrations, the Debye temperature, is determined by the strength of the interatomic coupling. Above the Debye temperature, the atoms appear as moving independently. In our correlated electron case, what corresponds to the Debye temperature is the coherence temperature, the temperature below which the conduction electrons settle into a coherent state characterized by very small scattering of conduction electrons by the local atomic magnetic moments, even though the strong coupling between conduction electrons and the local magnetic moments still remains. Above the coherence temperature, there is strong scattering of the conduction electrons by the atomic moments, clearly visible in the electrical resistivity.

     The discovery in this research has been that the coherence temperature is determined by the coupling of nearest neighbor atomic magnetic moments via their interaction with the conduction electrons. This has been demonstrated experimentally by comparing the single atomic moment coupling in iso-electronic  and iso-structural uncorrelated materials with the dense highly correlated compounds containing a regular lattice of the same atomic moments.

     The coherence temperature sets the overall energy scale for the electron physics in correlated electron systems. Its simple origin was not known prior to this study. 

     In the course of this project, graduate and postdoctoral students were trained in single crystal growth and physical property characterization. An extensive set of national and international collaborations was maintained, as well as providing measurement capabilities within UC Irvine for researchers from other Departments.
